manuscript.title: Kur'ân-ı Kerîm
manuscript.notes: Dated Quran (AH 1271 / CE 1854–55) in a standard late Ottoman luxury mushaf format. The catalogue notes an oxidized gilding condition (yer yer oksitlenmiş), and that a leaf has been torn from the back endpapers. The binding is detached from the spine board (sertabından ayrılmış) and the spine shows some wear. A kafes şemseli (lattice-pattern medallion) binding in brown leather with miklepli flap closure. Interior covered with green pandizot cloth. Despite the condition issues the decorative program is well-described by cataloguer Zeynep Özçelik.

paper_decoration.summary: A cross-category late Ottoman Quran with multiple decorative programs operating simultaneously. The opening bifolio (ilk iki sayfa) bears mülevven (colored) paper with nefis tezhip (fine illumination) and kenarları halkârî yaldızlı (gold halkâr margins). Gold cetvels frame the text throughout, with tinted cetvels visible in the screenshot (green/teal). Verse-divider duraklar are present and the hizib gül rosettes are described as mülevven tezhibli (colored/illuminated). Sûre çerçeveleri (surah frames) are yaldızlı (gilded). The gilding shows partial oxidation (yer yer oksitlenmiş). The halkârî program is confined to the opening bifolio — the rest of the manuscript relies on the gold cedvel framing and illuminated headpiece system. This is a standard high-quality late Ottoman Quran production pattern: luxury opening, with systematic gold ruling throughout.
paper_decoration.distribution_notes: Mülevven paper and halkârî margins are described as present on the ilk iki sayfa (first two pages — the opening bifolio). Gold cetvels and sûre çerçeveleri continue throughout. Hizib gülleri are mülevven tezhibli. The specific decorated opening bifolio was not captured in the IIIF screenshot (p004), which shows the body text with gold roundel duraklar and colored cetvels only.

key_indicators: Dated AH 1271 / CE 1854–55: a precisely dated late Ottoman Quran in a late Tanzimat-period production context
Cross-category decorative program (mülevven + halkâr + tezhip + gold cedvel) typical of Ottoman luxury mushaf production
Kafes şemseli binding with zencerek border is a conservative late Ottoman binding type, consistent with Istanbul or established provincial production
Mülevven tezhibli hizib gülleri and gilded sûre çerçeveleri are standard Quran production features of the period
cross_tradition_caveats: Late Ottoman Quran production (19th century) was geographically dispersed; without a colophon naming a city the distinction between Istanbul and a major Anatolian centre (e.g. Bursa, Konya, Kastamonu) cannot be made on available evidence
Partial oxidation of gilding noted; the condition may affect detailed stylistic comparisons
Opening bifolio (the primary decorated surface) not captured in the available IIIF screenshot

binding.cover_description_translation: Lattice-pattern (kafes) şemse medallion binding with zencerek (chain) border, brown leather (meşin) boards, miklep flap closure.

binding.notes: The kafes şemse is a conservative late Ottoman binding type with geometric lattice-pattern medallion. The zencerek (chain) border is a standard decorative element of Ottoman bindings from the 15th century onward, here used in a 19th-century context.

codicology.condition_summary: Partially worn: gold gilding shows oxidation in places; binding detached from spine; spine slightly worn; one leaf torn from back. The illuminated decoration of the opening bifolio appears intact based on catalogue description.

Gold roundel duraklar appear between verse groups, consistent with standard late Ottoman Quran production. folio_analyses.notes: The decorated opening bifolio described in the catalogue (mülevven + halkâr + fine tezhip) was not captured. The verdict of probable (0.65) rests on the catalogue description by Zeynep Özçelik, which is specific and technically precise: 'ilk iki sayfa mülevven, nefis tezhibli ve kenarları halkârî yaldızlı' is unambiguous in its identification of both the colored paper and the gold halkâr margins on the opening.

terms_used.english: Mülevven: dyed or colored paper. In Quran manuscripts the opening bifolio is sometimes produced on colored paper as a luxury marker, with the rest of the text block on plain paper. Here the mülevven treatment is combined with gold halkâr margins and fine illumination.

Halkâr/halkârî: shaded gold floral painting applied to the margins of manuscripts. In this Quran the halkâr is described as kenarları halkârî yaldızlı (gold halkâr margins) and is confined to the opening bifolio.

Hizib gülü: a decorative rosette marker in the text of a Quran indicating a ḥizb division (half-juzʾ, or one-sixtieth of the Quran). In this manuscript the hizib gülleri are mülevven tezhibli — colored and illuminated.

Kafes şemse: a binding medallion decorated with a geometric lattice (kafes = cage/lattice) pattern rather than the floral or arabesque designs of earlier Ottoman şemse types. Characteristic of 18th–19th century Ottoman binding production.

bibliography.relevance: Foundational taxonomic study of decorated papers in Islamic manuscripts. Directly relevant to the classification of the mülevven opening paper and gold halkâr margin painting program in this Quran.

bibliography.citation: Déroche, François. Islamic Codicology: An Introduction to the Study of Manuscripts in Arabic Script. Translated by Deke Dusinberre and David Radzinowicz. London: Al-Furqan Islamic Heritage Foundation, 2005.
bibliography.relevance: Foundational codicological reference covering Quran manuscript conventions including cedvel ruling, hizib and juzʾ markers, surah headpieces, and the physical structure of the mushaf — all directly relevant to cataloguing this manuscript.

bibliography.relevance: Survey of Ottoman Quran illumination traditions including the standard decorative program of mushaf manuscripts (opening bifolios, surah headpieces, verse dividers, hizib rosettes). Provides comparative context for the multi-element program documented in this late Ottoman Quran.
